facts.text: This is an appeal from a judgment and decree of the Bombay High Court by Stone C.J. and Coyajee J. dated 20th March 1947 in Appeal No. 42 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay. Civil Appeal No. XXVI of 1949. This was an appeal from a judgment and decree of the Bombay High Court  Stone C.J. and Coyajee J.  dated 20th March, 1947, in Appeal No. 42 of 1946, reversing a judgment of Chagla J. dismissing an application.

facts.text: The Bombay High Court reversed a judgment of Chagla J. dismissing an application made by the respondent under the Indian Arbitration Act 1940.

anchor.surface_text: reversing a judgment of Chagla J. dismissing an application. made by the respond- ent under the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, praying inter alia that the arbitration agreement companytained in certain companytract numberes sent by the appellants to the respondent be declared invalid and void and for setting aside an award made by arbitrators appointed under the said companytract numbere.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. XXVI of 1949 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay. Civil Appeal No. XXVI of 1949.

facts.text: Appellants are members of the East India Cotton Association Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants were and are members of the East India Cotton Association Ltd. The Respondent, however, was number and is number a member of that Association.

facts.text: Respondent was and is not a member of the East India Cotton Association Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondent, however, was number and is number a member of that Association.

facts.text: In April 1945, the Respondent employed the Appellants as his agents to effect forward contracts for the sale and/or purchase of cotton according to the rules of the Association.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1945, the Respondent employed the Appellants as his agents to effect forward companytracts for the sale and or purchase of companyton according to the rules, regulations and bye-laws of that Association.

facts.text: Between 9th April 1945 and 10th August 1945, Appellants put through various contracts for sale/purchase of cotton for July 1945 and September 1945 deliveries and sent contract notes to Respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Between the 9th April, 1945, and the 10th August, 1945, the Appellants as such agents put through various companytracts for sale and or purchase of companyton for July, 1945, and September, 1945, deliveries and sent to the Respondent companytract numberes in respect of each of such companytracts.

facts.text: On 10th August 1945, purchase of 900 bales of cotton at Rs. 432 per candy for September 1945 delivery remained outstanding.

anchor.surface_text: On the 10th August, 1945, the purchase of 900 bales of companyton at Rs. 432 per candy for September 1945 delivery remained outstanding.

facts.text: Respondent claims that on 11th August 1945, he instructed Appellants to close the outstanding purchase by selling 900 bales for September 1945 at not less than Rs. 426 per candy.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Respondent, on the 11th August, 1945, the Respondent instructed the Appellants to close the said outstanding purchase by selling 900 bales for September 1945 delivery at a rate number less than Rs. 426 per candy, which is said to be the prevailing market rate on that date.

facts.text: Appellants deny receiving any instruction from Respondent on 11th August 1945 to close the contract.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants, however, deny that any instruction was given by the Respond- ent on the 11th August, 1945, for closing the outstanding companytract. They deny the receipt of the Respondents letter of that date.

facts.text: On 18th August 1945, Respondent put instructions on record and asked for contract note.

anchor.surface_text: As the Respondent did number receive any companytract numbere from the Appellants in respect of the closing transac- tion of 900 bales, the Respondent on the 18th August, 1945, put on record his aforesaid instructions and asked the Appellants to send the companytract numbere.

facts.text: 21st August 1945 was a clearing date and Rs. 18,900 became due by Respondent to Appellants.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Appellants the 21st August, 1945, was a clearing date and on that clearing a sum of Rs. 18,900 became due and payable by the Respondent to the Appellants

facts.text: Appellants by letter dated 22nd August 1945 repudiated Respondent's allegations and demanded Rs. 18,900 by 23rd August 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants by their letter of the 22nd August, 1945, repudiated the allegations in the Respondents last men- tioned letter and called upon the Respondent to pay up Rs. 18,900 and gave numberice to him that if he failed to pay up the amount by numbern of the 23rd August, 1945,

facts.text: On 24th August 1945, Respondent denied liability for Rs. 18,900 and returned the bill.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondent on the 24th August, 1945, denied having fabricated any false story and repudiated liability for Rs. 18,900 and returned the Appellants bill.

facts.text: On 27th August 1945, Appellants closed the contract by selling 900 bales at Rs. 356 per candy and sent contract note No. 17996.

anchor.surface_text: On the 27th August, 1945, the Appellants closed the outstanding companytract for purchase of 900 bales by selling the same at Rs. 356 per candy for September 1945 delivery and along with their letter dated the 27th August, 1945, sent companytract numbere No. 17996.

facts.text: On 28th August 1945, Respondent reiterated previous instructions, denied new instructions, and returned contract note No. 17996.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondent by his letter dated the 28th August, 1945, reit- erated the story of previous instruction for closing the companytract, denied having given any instruction to the Appel- lants to close the companytract on the 27th August, 1945, and returned the companytract numbere No. 17996.

facts.text: On 28th August 1945, Appellants claimed Rs. 34,313 and desired reference to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th August, 1945, the Appellants wrote to the Respondent claiming Rs. 34,313 and expressing the desire to refer the disputes to arbitration in terms of the arbitration agreement companytained in the companytract numberes.

facts.text: Both parties appointed arbitrators who fixed meeting for 24th October 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties appointed their respec- tive arbitrators. The arbitrators entered upon the refer- ence and eventually fixed the 24th October, 1945, for a meeting of the arbitrators.

facts.text: Arbitrators made ex parte award on 24th October 1945 for Rs. 34,313 and interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrators, however, rejected the application for adjournment and made an ex parte award on the same day for Rs. 34,313 and interest and companyts.

facts.text: Respondent filed appeal to the Board of the Association on 10th November 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the award the Respondent on the 10th November, 1945, filed an appeal to the Board of the Association.

facts.text: Chagla J. dismissed the Respondent's application on 2nd July 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was dealt with by Mr. Justice Chagla who overruled the companytentions of the Respondent and dismissed the application on 2nd July 1946.

facts.text: Bombay High Court (Stone C.J. and Coyajee J.) accepted Respondent's appeal, set aside dismissal, declared arbitration agreement invalid, set aside award.

anchor.surface_text: who accepted the appeal, set aside the dismissal of the Respond- ents petition and gave the declaration prayed for and set aside the award.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with the decision of the appellate Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.

facts.text: East India Cotton Association is a recognised cotton association under Bombay Cotton Contracts Act 1932.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the East India Cotton Associa- tion is one of the recognised companyton associations for the purposes of the said Act.

facts.text: Contract notes sent by Appellants did not include the required deposit clause for Rs. 12.5 per bale and had outdated rubber stamp for Rs. 25 per bale.

anchor.surface_text: In the companytract numbere rendered by the Appellants to the Respondent the last sentence providing for deposit at the end of the margin clause is missing. There is, however, a rubber stamp impression... Rs. 25 per bale
under the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, praying inter alia that the arbitration agreement contained in certain contract notes sent by the appellants to the respondent be declared invalid and void

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 i of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, runs as follows - Save as hereinafter provided in this Act any contract whether either party thereto is a member of a recognised cotton association or not which is entered into after the date on which this Act comes into operation and which is not in accordance with the bye-laws of any recognised cotton association shall be void.

concepts.interpretation: Contracts not in accordance with bye-laws of recognised cotton association are void

issues.text: Whether the contract notes actually issued by the Appellants to the Respondent were in accordance with the bye-laws of the East India Cotton Association and consequently whether the contracts were void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent was that the contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye- laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract notes was also void and there could be no reference to arbitration and there could be no award as purported to have been made by the arbitrators on a reference under the void contracts.

issues.text: Whether Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932 only voids contracts not made subject to bye-laws, regardless of whether the contract notes rendered are in the prescribed form

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge was of the opinion that section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, only avoided the contracts in case of contravention of the first requirement, namely, if the contracts were not made subject to the bye-laws, but had no concern with the contravention of the second requirement, namely, if the contract notes were not in the prescribed form.

issues.text: Whether, when a contract is reduced to writing, the writing is the repository of the contract and non-compliance with bye-laws in that writing renders the contract void

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye-laws, the contract itself must be void.

issues.text: Whether a pre-existing oral contract between agent and constituent complies with bye-laws if its terms match the non-compliant written contract note

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, feel pressed to emphasize this aspect of the matter, for, assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

issues.text: Whether the rubber stamp impression stating deposit at a rate not less than Rs. 25 per bale complies with the amended bye-law 51-A requiring not less than Rs. 12-1/2 per bale

anchor.surface_text: In the first place we find that the last sentence in the margin clause, in order to be in accordance with the bye-laws, should have been as follows - In addition to the above, the deposit not carrying interest payable under bye-law 51-A, namely, at a rate not less than Rs. 12 1/2 per bale shall, when demanded, be made by you to me us in Bombay.

issues.text: Whether the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarizes bye-law 51-A after its amendment

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this consideration there is another serious objection to the rubber stamp provision. The language of that rubber stamp provision clearly indicates that it purports to summarise and set out what is payable under bye-law 51-A.

issues.text: Whether omission of the two specific clauses relating to bye-law 65-A from the contract note renders it non-compliant, or whether incorporation by reference to bye-laws suffices

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the Respondent has been and is that by reason of the omission of the two clauses at the end of the contract note actually issued by the Appellants it was not in accordance with the bye-laws. The learned Attorney-General appearing for the Appellants contends that the contract was expressly made subject to the bye-laws and, therefore, the provisions of the new bye-law 65-A were by reference incorporated in the contract.

issues.text: Whether the arbitration agreement contained in the contract notes is valid and enforceable given the invalidity of the underlying contracts

anchor.surface_text: under the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, praying inter alia that the arbitration agreement contained in certain contract notes including contract note No. 17996 sent by the Appellants to the Respondent be declared to be invalid, void and unenforceable and be set aside and that a purported award made by the arbitrators appointed in terms of the said contract notes be set aside.

arguments.claim: The contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye-laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract notes was also void

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent was that the contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye- laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract notes was also void and there could be no reference to arbitration and there could be no award as purported to have been made by the arbitrators on a reference under the void contracts.

In other words, any rate above the rate of Rs. 12 1/2 may be stipulated in accordance with the terms of business

arguments.court_reasoning: Bye-law 65-A regulates members inter se; meaningless for non-member constituent; specific clauses required in note, not just reference

arguments.claim: When a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye-laws, the contract itself must be void

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye-laws, the contract itself must be void.

arguments.claim: Assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, ... we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, feel pressed to emphasize this aspect of the matter, for, assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

arguments.claim: The last sentence in the margin clause should have been ... at a rate not less than Rs. 12 1/2 per bale; rubber stamp with Rs. 25 is non-compliant

anchor.surface_text: There is no suggestion that the terms of the so called pre-existing oral contract were in any way different from the terms subsequently recorded in the contract notes actually issued. In the first place we find that the last sentence in the margin clause, in order to be in accordance with the bye-laws, should have been as follows - In addition to the above, the deposit not carrying interest payable under bye-law 51-A, namely, at a rate not less than Rs. 12 1/2 per bale

arguments.claim: The rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constituent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accordance with bye-law 51-A

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the opening clause of the contract note makes the contract subject to the Appellants usual charges and terms of business, but the contract is at the same time subject to the bye-laws of the Association. In order to reconcile the two, such terms of business as are not inconsistent with the bye-laws can only be permitted to prevail.

arguments.claim: The language of that rubber stamp provision clearly indicates that it purports to summarise and set out what is payable under bye-law 51-A ... the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarises and sets out the provisions of bye-law 51-A and consequently is not in accordance with that bye-law

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this consideration there is another serious objection to the rubber stamp provision. The language of that rubber stamp provision clearly indicates that it purports to summarise and set out what is payable under bye-law 51-A. In fact, as already stated,above, bye-law 51-A had been amended and what is payable under the amended bye-law is not at a rate not less than Rs. 25 but at a rate not less than Rs. 12 1/2.

arguments.claim: Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless

anchor.surface_text: This contention, we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless. Further, under bye-law 65-A the last buyer has certain options.

holdings.text: We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: who accepted the appeal, set aside the dismissal of the Respond- ents petition and gave the declaration prayed for and set aside the award. The Appellants have now come up on appeal before us after having obtained the necessary certificate from the Bombay High Court. We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After detailed analysis of contract note defects re bye-laws 51-A and 65-A, court concurs with High Court that contracts void u/s 8 Bombay Act, arbitration invalid, award set aside.

holdings.text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye-laws, the contract itself must be void.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye- laws, the contract itself must be void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard contract principle: written document embodies entire agreement; must comply with mandatory bye-law form requirements under S.8.

holdings.text: assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, feel pressed to emphasize this aspect of the matter, for, assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even hypothetical oral agreement must independently satisfy bye-law compliance for validity u/s 8; terms matched non-compliant notes.

holdings.text: the rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constituent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accordance with bye-law 51-A.

anchor.surface_text: The rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constituent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accordance with bye-law 51-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended bye-law 51-A mandates min Rs 12.5/bale; Rs 25 stamp exceeds and conflicts as specific contract term inconsistent with bye-law minimum.

holdings.text: the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarises and sets out the provisions of bye-law 51-A and consequently is not in accordance with that bye-law.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this consideration there is another serious objection to the rubber stamp provision. The language of that rubber stamp provision clearly indicates that it purports to summarise and set out what is payable under bye-law 51-A. ... Therefore, the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarises and sets out the provisions of bye-law 51-A and consequently is not in accordance with that bye-law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stamp purports to state amended bye-law content but reflects outdated pre-amendment rate, misstating law.

holdings.text: This contention [that reference to bye-laws incorporates 65-A], we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the Respondent has been and is that by reason of the omission of the two clauses at the end of the contract note actually issued by the Appellants it was not in accordance with the bye-laws. The learned Attorney-General appearing for the Appellants contends that the contract was expressly made subject to the bye-laws and, therefore, the provisions of the new bye-law 65-A were by reference incorporated in the contract. This contention, we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bye-law 65-A governs inter-member options irrelevant to non-member; general reference inadequate, specific clauses required for constituent obligations.

holdings.text: the contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye-laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract notes was also void.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent was that the contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye- laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract notes was also void and there could be no reference to arbitration and there could be no award as purported to have been made by the arbitrators on a reference under the void contracts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-compliant notes void underlying contracts u/s 8; embedded arbitration clause falls with them.

anchor.surface_text: who accepted the appeal, set aside the dismissal of the Respond- ents petition and gave the declaration prayed for and set aside the award. The Appellants have now come up on appeal before us after having obtained the necessary certificate from the Bombay High Court. We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.

We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a companytract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the companytract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the companytract between the parties is, and if that writing is number in accordance with the bye-laws, the companytract itself must be void.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 articulates the principle that the writing becomes the repository of the contract, establishing the concept c10 of written contract as repository. [REPAIRED: establishes->supports]
h2's holding on writing as repository grounds h3's further reasoning on pre-existing oral contracts. [REPAIRED: grounds->supports]
h2 emphasizes compliance via writing/contract notes, rebutting i2/a2's claim that notes are irrelevant. [REPAIRED: rebuts->addresses]
h2 holds writing is repository of contract, resolving i3 affirmatively.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a companytract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the companytract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the companytract between the parties is, and if that writing is number in accordance with the bye-laws, the companytract itself must be void.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 assumes a pre-existing oral contract dehors the written note and states we must still check its compliance, directly addressing whether such an oral contract complies merely if terms match the non-compliant written note.
h3 assumes pre-existing oral contract but requires checking its compliance with bye-laws, partially resolving i4.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, feel pressed to emphasize this aspect of the matter, for, assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a companytract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the companytract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the companytract between the parties is, and if that writing is number in accordance with the bye-laws, the companytract itself must be void.

The rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constituent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accordance with bye-law 51-A.

We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a companytract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the companytract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the companytract between the parties is, and if that writing is number in accordance with the bye-laws, the companytract itself must be void.

Apart from this consideration there is another serious objection to the rubber stamp provision. The language of that rubber stamp provision clearly indicates that it purports to summarise and set out what is payable under bye-law 51-A. ... Therefore, the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarises and sets out the provisions of bye-law 51-A and consequently is not in accordance with that bye-law.

We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a companytract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the companytract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the companytract between the parties is, and if that writing is number in accordance with the bye-laws, the companytract itself must be void.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent was that the contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye- laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract notes was also void and there could be no reference to arbitration and there could be no award as purported to have been made by the arbitrators on a reference under the void contracts.

We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a companytract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the companytract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the companytract between the parties is, and if that writing is number in accordance with the bye-laws, the companytract itself must be void.
